trans-unit.source: Install and Use Windows PowerShell Web Access
trans-unit.target: Install and Use Windows PowerShell Web Access

trans-unit.source: Updated: November 5, 2013
trans-unit.target: Updated: November 5, 2013

trans-unit.source: Applies To: Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012
trans-unit.target: Applies To: Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2012

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell® Web Access, first introduced in Windows Server® 2012, acts as a Windows PowerShell gateway, providing a web-based Windows PowerShell console that is targeted at a remote computer.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell® Web Access, first introduced in Windows Server® 2012, acts as a Windows PowerShell gateway, providing a web-based Windows PowerShell console that is targeted at a remote computer.

trans-unit.source: It enables IT Pros to run Windows PowerShell commands and scripts from a Windows PowerShell console in a web browser, with no Windows PowerShell, remote management software, or browser plug-in installation necessary on the client device.
trans-unit.target: It enables IT Pros to run Windows PowerShell commands and scripts from a Windows PowerShell console in a web browser, with no Windows PowerShell, remote management software, or browser plug-in installation necessary on the client device.

trans-unit.source: All that is required to run the web-based Windows PowerShell console is a properly-configured Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway, and a client device browser that supports JavaScript® and accepts cookies.
trans-unit.target: All that is required to run the web-based Windows PowerShell console is a properly-configured Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway, and a client device browser that supports JavaScript® and accepts cookies.

trans-unit.source: Examples of client devices include laptops, non-work personal computers, borrowed computers, tablet computers, web kiosks, computers that are not running a Windows-based operating system, and cell phone browsers.
trans-unit.target: Examples of client devices include laptops, non-work personal computers, borrowed computers, tablet computers, web kiosks, computers that are not running a Windows-based operating system, and cell phone browsers.

trans-unit.source: IT Pros can perform critical management tasks on remote Windows-based servers from devices that have access to an Internet connection and a web browser.
trans-unit.target: IT Pros can perform critical management tasks on remote Windows-based servers from devices that have access to an Internet connection and a web browser.

trans-unit.source: After successful gateway setup and configuration, users can access a Windows PowerShell console by using a web browser.
trans-unit.target: After successful gateway setup and configuration, users can access a Windows PowerShell console by using a web browser.

trans-unit.source: When users open the secured Windows PowerShell Web Access website, they can run a web-based Windows PowerShell console after successful authentication.
trans-unit.target: When users open the secured Windows PowerShell Web Access website, they can run a web-based Windows PowerShell console after successful authentication.

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell Web Access setup and configuration is a three-step process:
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell Web Access setup and configuration is a three-step process:

trans-unit.source: Installing Windows PowerShell Web Access
trans-unit.target: Installing Windows PowerShell Web Access

trans-unit.source: Configuring the gateway
trans-unit.target: Configuring the gateway

trans-unit.source: Configuring authorization rules that allow users access to the web-based Windows PowerShell console
trans-unit.target: Configuring authorization rules that allow users access to the web-based Windows PowerShell console

trans-unit.source: Before you install and configure Windows PowerShell Web Access, we recommend that you read this entire guide, which includes instructions about how to install, secure, and uninstall Windows PowerShell Web Access.
trans-unit.target: Before you install and configure Windows PowerShell Web Access, we recommend that you read this entire guide, which includes instructions about how to install, secure, and uninstall Windows PowerShell Web Access.

trans-unit.source: The [Use the Web-based Windows PowerShell Console](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh831417(v=ws.11).aspx) topic describes how users sign in to the web-based console, and covers limitations and differences between the web-based Windows PowerShell console and the **powershell.exe** console.
trans-unit.target: The [Use the Web-based Windows PowerShell Console](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh831417(v=ws.11).aspx) topic describes how users sign in to the web-based console, and covers limitations and differences between the web-based Windows PowerShell console and the **powershell.exe** console.

trans-unit.source: End users of the web-based console should read [Use the Web-based Windows PowerShell Console](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh831417(v=ws.11).aspx), but do not need to read the rest of this guide.
trans-unit.target: End users of the web-based console should read [Use the Web-based Windows PowerShell Console](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh831417(v=ws.11).aspx), but do not need to read the rest of this guide.

trans-unit.source: This topic does not provide in-depth Web Server (IIS) operations guidance; only those steps required to configure the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway are described in this topic.
trans-unit.target: This topic does not provide in-depth Web Server (IIS) operations guidance; only those steps required to configure the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway are described in this topic.

trans-unit.source: For more information about configuring and securing websites in IIS, see the IIS documentation resources in the See Also section.
trans-unit.target: For more information about configuring and securing websites in IIS, see the IIS documentation resources in the See Also section.

trans-unit.source: Requirements for running Windows PowerShell Web Access
trans-unit.target: Requirements for running Windows PowerShell Web Access

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell Web Access requires Web Server (IIS), .NET Framework 4.5, and Windows PowerShell 3.0 or Windows PowerShell 4.0 to be running on the server on which you want to run the gateway.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell Web Access requires Web Server (IIS), .NET Framework 4.5, and Windows PowerShell 3.0 or Windows PowerShell 4.0 to be running on the server on which you want to run the gateway.

trans-unit.source: You can install Windows PowerShell Web Access on a server that is running Windows Server 2012 R2 or Windows Server 2012 by using either the Add Roles and Features Wizard in Server Manager, or Windows PowerShell deployment cmdlets for Server Manager.
trans-unit.target: You can install Windows PowerShell Web Access on a server that is running Windows Server 2012 R2 or Windows Server 2012 by using either the Add Roles and Features Wizard in Server Manager, or Windows PowerShell deployment cmdlets for Server Manager.

trans-unit.source: When you install Windows PowerShell Web Access by using Server Manager or its deployment cmdlets, required roles and features are automatically added as part of the installation process.
trans-unit.target: When you install Windows PowerShell Web Access by using Server Manager or its deployment cmdlets, required roles and features are automatically added as part of the installation process.

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell Web Access allows remote users to access computers in your organization by using Windows PowerShell in a web browser.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell Web Access allows remote users to access computers in your organization by using Windows PowerShell in a web browser.

trans-unit.source: Although Windows PowerShell Web Access is a convenient and powerful management tool, the web-based access poses security risks, and should be configured as securely as possible.
trans-unit.target: Although Windows PowerShell Web Access is a convenient and powerful management tool, the web-based access poses security risks, and should be configured as securely as possible.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that administrators who configure the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway use available security layers, both the cmdlet-based authorization rules included with Windows PowerShell Web Access, and security layers that are available in Web Server (IIS) and third-party applications.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that administrators who configure the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway use available security layers, both the cmdlet-based authorization rules included with Windows PowerShell Web Access, and security layers that are available in Web Server (IIS) and third-party applications.

trans-unit.source: This documentation includes both unsecure examples that are only recommended for test environments, as well as examples that are recommended for secure deployments.
trans-unit.target: This documentation includes both unsecure examples that are only recommended for test environments, as well as examples that are recommended for secure deployments.

trans-unit.source: Browser and client device support
trans-unit.target: Browser and client device support

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell Web Access supports the following Internet browsers.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell Web Access supports the following Internet browsers.

trans-unit.source: Although mobile browsers are not officially supported, many may be able to run the web-based Windows PowerShell console.
trans-unit.target: Although mobile browsers are not officially supported, many may be able to run the web-based Windows PowerShell console.

trans-unit.source: Other browsers that accept cookies, run JavaScript, and run HTTPS websites are expected to work, but are not officially tested.
trans-unit.target: Other browsers that accept cookies, run JavaScript, and run HTTPS websites are expected to work, but are not officially tested.

trans-unit.source: Supported desktop computer browsers
trans-unit.target: Supported desktop computer browsers

trans-unit.source: Windows® Internet Explorer® for Microsoft Windows® 8.0, 9.0, 10.0, and 11.0
trans-unit.target: Windows® Internet Explorer® for Microsoft Windows® 8.0, 9.0, 10.0, and 11.0

trans-unit.source: Mozilla Firefox® 10.0.2
trans-unit.target: Mozilla Firefox® 10.0.2

trans-unit.source: Google Chrome™ 17.0.963.56m for Windows
trans-unit.target: Google Chrome™ 17.0.963.56m for Windows

trans-unit.source: Apple Safari® 5.1.2 for Windows
trans-unit.target: Apple Safari® 5.1.2 for Windows

trans-unit.source: Apple Safari 5.1.2 for Mac OS®
trans-unit.target: Apple Safari 5.1.2 for Mac OS®

trans-unit.target: Minimally-tested mobile devices or browsers

trans-unit.source: Windows Phone 7 and 7.5
trans-unit.target: Windows Phone 7 and 7.5

trans-unit.source: Google Android WebKit 3.1 Browser Android 2.2.1 (Kernel 2.6)
trans-unit.target: Google Android WebKit 3.1 Browser Android 2.2.1 (Kernel 2.6)

trans-unit.target: Apple Safari for iPhone operating system 5.0.1

trans-unit.source: Browser requirements
trans-unit.target: Browser requirements

trans-unit.source: To use the Windows PowerShell Web Access web-based console, browsers must do the following.
trans-unit.target: To use the Windows PowerShell Web Access web-based console, browsers must do the following.

trans-unit.source: Allow cookies from the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway website.
trans-unit.target: Allow cookies from the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway website.

trans-unit.source: Be able to open and read HTTPS pages.
trans-unit.target: Be able to open and read HTTPS pages.

trans-unit.source: Open and run websites that use JavaScript.
trans-unit.target: Open and run websites that use JavaScript.

trans-unit.source: Recommended (quick) deployment
trans-unit.target: Recommended (quick) deployment

trans-unit.source: You can install the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway on a server that is running Windows Server 2012 R2 or Windows Server 2012 by using either Windows PowerShell cmdlets, or by using the Add Roles and Features Wizard that is opened from within Server Manager.
trans-unit.target: You can install the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway on a server that is running Windows Server 2012 R2 or Windows Server 2012 by using either Windows PowerShell cmdlets, or by using the Add Roles and Features Wizard that is opened from within Server Manager.

trans-unit.source: For quick installation and configuration, use Windows PowerShell cmdlets, as described in this section.
trans-unit.target: For quick installation and configuration, use Windows PowerShell cmdlets, as described in this section.

trans-unit.source: [Step 1: Install Windows PowerShell Web Access](#BKMK_step1)
trans-unit.target: [Step 1: Install Windows PowerShell Web Access](#BKMK_step1)

trans-unit.source: [Step 2: Configure the gateway](#BKMK_step2)
trans-unit.target: [Step 2: Configure the gateway](#BKMK_step2)

trans-unit.source: [Step 3: Configure a restrictive authorization rule](#BKMK_step3)
trans-unit.target: [Step 3: Configure a restrictive authorization rule](#BKMK_step3)

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Install Windows PowerShell Web Access
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Install Windows PowerShell Web Access

trans-unit.source: To install Windows PowerShell Web Access by using Windows PowerShell cmdlets
trans-unit.target: To install Windows PowerShell Web Access by using Windows PowerShell cmdlets

trans-unit.source: Do one of the following to open a Windows PowerShell session with elevated user rights.
trans-unit.target: Do one of the following to open a Windows PowerShell session with elevated user rights.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows desktop, right-click **Windows PowerShell** on the taskbar, and then click **Run as Administrator**.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows desktop, right-click **Windows PowerShell** on the taskbar, and then click **Run as Administrator**.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows **Start** screen, right-click **Windows PowerShell**, and then click **Run as Administrator**.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows **Start** screen, right-click **Windows PowerShell**, and then click **Run as Administrator**.

trans-unit.source: Note
trans-unit.target: Note

trans-unit.source: In Windows PowerShell 3.0 and 4.0, there is no need to import the Server Manager cmdlet module into the Windows PowerShell session before running cmdlets that are part of the module.
trans-unit.target: In Windows PowerShell 3.0 and 4.0, there is no need to import the Server Manager cmdlet module into the Windows PowerShell session before running cmdlets that are part of the module.

trans-unit.source: A module is automatically imported the first time you run a cmdlet that is part of the module.
trans-unit.target: A module is automatically imported the first time you run a cmdlet that is part of the module.

trans-unit.source: Also, Windows PowerShell cmdlets are not case-sensitive.
trans-unit.target: Also, Windows PowerShell cmdlets are not case-sensitive.

trans-unit.source: Type the following, and then press **Enter**, where *computer_name* represents a remote computer on which you want to install Windows PowerShell Web Access, if applicable.
trans-unit.target: Type the following, and then press **Enter**, where *computer_name* represents a remote computer on which you want to install Windows PowerShell Web Access, if applicable.

trans-unit.source: The Restart parameter automatically restarts destination servers if required.
trans-unit.target: The Restart parameter automatically restarts destination servers if required.

trans-unit.source: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_374a9c21-4f6e-471e-b957-bb190a594533'); "Copy to clipboard.")
trans-unit.target: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_374a9c21-4f6e-471e-b957-bb190a594533'); "Copy to clipboard.")

trans-unit.source: Note
trans-unit.target: Note

trans-unit.source: Installing Windows PowerShell Web Access by using Windows PowerShell cmdlets does not add Web Server (IIS) management tools by default.
trans-unit.target: Installing Windows PowerShell Web Access by using Windows PowerShell cmdlets does not add Web Server (IIS) management tools by default.

trans-unit.source: If you want to install the management tools on the same server as the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway, add the IncludeManagementTools parameter to the installation command (as provided in this step).
trans-unit.target: If you want to install the management tools on the same server as the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway, add the IncludeManagementTools parameter to the installation command (as provided in this step).

trans-unit.source: If you are managing the Windows PowerShell Web Access website from a remote computer, install the IIS Manager snap-in by installing Remote Server Administration Tools for Windows 8.1 or Remote Server Administration Tools for Windows 8 on the computer from which you want to manage the gateway.
trans-unit.target: If you are managing the Windows PowerShell Web Access website from a remote computer, install the IIS Manager snap-in by installing Remote Server Administration Tools for Windows 8.1 or Remote Server Administration Tools for Windows 8 on the computer from which you want to manage the gateway.

trans-unit.source: To install roles and features on an offline VHD, you must add both the ComputerName parameter and the VHD parameter.
trans-unit.target: To install roles and features on an offline VHD, you must add both the ComputerName parameter and the VHD parameter.

trans-unit.source: The ComputerName parameter contains the name of the server on which to mount the VHD, and the VHD parameter contains the path to the VHD file on the specified server.
trans-unit.target: The ComputerName parameter contains the name of the server on which to mount the VHD, and the VHD parameter contains the path to the VHD file on the specified server.

trans-unit.source: When installation is complete, verify that Windows PowerShell Web Access was installed on destination servers by running the **Get-WindowsFeature** cmdlet on a destination server, in a Windows PowerShell console that has been opened with elevated user rights.
trans-unit.target: When installation is complete, verify that Windows PowerShell Web Access was installed on destination servers by running the **Get-WindowsFeature** cmdlet on a destination server, in a Windows PowerShell console that has been opened with elevated user rights.

trans-unit.source: You can also verify that Windows PowerShell Web Access was installed in the Server Manager console, by selecting a destination server on the **All Servers** page, and then viewing the **Roles and Features** tile for the selected server.
trans-unit.target: You can also verify that Windows PowerShell Web Access was installed in the Server Manager console, by selecting a destination server on the **All Servers** page, and then viewing the **Roles and Features** tile for the selected server.

trans-unit.source: You can also view the readme file for Windows PowerShell Web Access.
trans-unit.target: You can also view the readme file for Windows PowerShell Web Access.

trans-unit.source: After Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed, you are prompted to review the readme file, which contains basic, required setup instructions for the gateway.
trans-unit.target: After Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed, you are prompted to review the readme file, which contains basic, required setup instructions for the gateway.

trans-unit.source: These setup instructions are also in the following section, [Step 2: Configure the gateway](#BKMK_step2).
trans-unit.target: These setup instructions are also in the following section, [Step 2: Configure the gateway](#BKMK_step2).

trans-unit.source: The path to the readme file is C:\\Windows\\Web\\PowerShellWebAccess\\wwwroot\\README.txt.
trans-unit.target: The path to the readme file is C:\\Windows\\Web\\PowerShellWebAccess\\wwwroot\\README.txt.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Configure the gateway
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Configure the gateway

trans-unit.source: The **Install-PswaWebApplication** cmdlet is a quick way to get Windows PowerShell Web Access configured.
trans-unit.target: The **Install-PswaWebApplication** cmdlet is a quick way to get Windows PowerShell Web Access configured.

trans-unit.source: Although you can add the UseTestCertificate parameter to the Install-PswaWebApplication cmdlet to install a self-signed SSL certificate for test purposes, this is not secure; for a secure production environment, always use a valid SSL certificate that has been signed by a certification authority (CA).
trans-unit.target: Although you can add the UseTestCertificate parameter to the Install-PswaWebApplication cmdlet to install a self-signed SSL certificate for test purposes, this is not secure; for a secure production environment, always use a valid SSL certificate that has been signed by a certification authority (CA).

trans-unit.source: Administrators can replace the test certificate with a signed certificate of their choice by using the IIS Manager console.
trans-unit.target: Administrators can replace the test certificate with a signed certificate of their choice by using the IIS Manager console.

trans-unit.source: You can complete Windows PowerShell Web Access web application configuration either by running the Install-PswaWebApplication cmdlet or by performing GUI-based configuration steps in IIS Manager.
trans-unit.target: You can complete Windows PowerShell Web Access web application configuration either by running the Install-PswaWebApplication cmdlet or by performing GUI-based configuration steps in IIS Manager.

trans-unit.source: By default, the cmdlet installs the web application, **pswa** (and an application pool for it, **pswa_pool**), in the **Default Web Site** container, as shown in IIS Manager; if desired, you can instruct the cmdlet to change the default site container of the web application.
trans-unit.target: By default, the cmdlet installs the web application, **pswa** (and an application pool for it, **pswa_pool**), in the **Default Web Site** container, as shown in IIS Manager; if desired, you can instruct the cmdlet to change the default site container of the web application.

trans-unit.source: IIS Manager offers configuration options that are available for web applications, such as changing the port number or the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) certificate.
trans-unit.target: IIS Manager offers configuration options that are available for web applications, such as changing the port number or the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) certificate.

trans-unit.source: Security Note
trans-unit.target: Security Note

trans-unit.source: We strongly recommend that administrators configure the gateway to use a valid certificate that has been signed by a CA.
trans-unit.target: We strongly recommend that administrators configure the gateway to use a valid certificate that has been signed by a CA.

trans-unit.source: [To configure the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway with a test certificate by using Install-PswaWebApplication](#BKMK_testcert)
trans-unit.target: [To configure the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway with a test certificate by using Install-PswaWebApplication](#BKMK_testcert)

trans-unit.source: [To configure the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway with a genuine certificate by using Install-PswaWebApplication and IIS Manager](#BKMK_gencert)
trans-unit.target: [To configure the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway with a genuine certificate by using Install-PswaWebApplication and IIS Manager](#BKMK_gencert)

trans-unit.source: To configure the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway with a test certificate by using Install-PswaWebApplication
trans-unit.target: To configure the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway with a test certificate by using Install-PswaWebApplication

trans-unit.source: Do one of the following to open a Windows PowerShell session.
trans-unit.target: Do one of the following to open a Windows PowerShell session.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows desktop, right-click **Windows PowerShell** on the taskbar.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows desktop, right-click **Windows PowerShell** on the taskbar.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows **Start** screen, click **Windows PowerShell**.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows **Start** screen, click **Windows PowerShell**.

trans-unit.source: Type the following, and then press **Enter**.
trans-unit.target: Type the following, and then press **Enter**.

trans-unit.source: **Install-PswaWebApplication -UseTestCertificate**
trans-unit.target: **Install-PswaWebApplication -UseTestCertificate**

trans-unit.source: Security Note
trans-unit.target: Security Note

trans-unit.source: The UseTestCertificate parameter should only be used in a private test environment.
trans-unit.target: The UseTestCertificate parameter should only be used in a private test environment.

trans-unit.source: For a secure production environment, we recommend using a valid certificate that has been signed by a CA.
trans-unit.target: For a secure production environment, we recommend using a valid certificate that has been signed by a CA.

trans-unit.source: Running the cmdlet installs the Windows PowerShell Web Access web application within the IIS Default Web Site container.
trans-unit.target: Running the cmdlet installs the Windows PowerShell Web Access web application within the IIS Default Web Site container.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet creates the infrastructure required to run Windows PowerShell Web Access on the default website, https://<server_name>/pswa.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet creates the infrastructure required to run Windows PowerShell Web Access on the default website, https://<server_name>/pswa.

trans-unit.source: To install the web application in a different website, provide the website name by adding the WebSiteName parameter.
trans-unit.target: To install the web application in a different website, provide the website name by adding the WebSiteName parameter.

trans-unit.source: To change the name of the web application (the default is pswa), add the WebApplicationName parameter.
trans-unit.target: To change the name of the web application (the default is pswa), add the WebApplicationName parameter.

trans-unit.source: The following settings are configured by running the cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: The following settings are configured by running the cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: You can change these manually in the IIS Manager console, if desired.
trans-unit.target: You can change these manually in the IIS Manager console, if desired.

trans-unit.source: Path: /pswa
trans-unit.target: Path: /pswa

trans-unit.source: ApplicationPool: pswa_pool
trans-unit.target: ApplicationPool: pswa_pool

trans-unit.source: EnabledProtocols: http
trans-unit.target: EnabledProtocols: http

trans-unit.source: PhysicalPath: %*windir*%/Web/PowerShellWebAccess/wwwroot
trans-unit.target: PhysicalPath: %*windir*%/Web/PowerShellWebAccess/wwwroot

trans-unit.source: Example: Install-PswaWebApplication –webApplicationName myWebApp –useTestCertificate
trans-unit.target: Example: Install-PswaWebApplication –webApplicationName myWebApp –useTestCertificate

trans-unit.source: In this example, the resulting website for Windows PowerShell Web Access is https://< *server_name*>/myWebApp.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the resulting website for Windows PowerShell Web Access is https://< *server_name*>/myWebApp.

trans-unit.source: Note
trans-unit.target: Note

trans-unit.source: You cannot sign in until users have been granted access to the website by adding authorization rules.
trans-unit.target: You cannot sign in until users have been granted access to the website by adding authorization rules.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see Step 3: Configure a restrictive authorization rule and Authorization Rules and Security Features of Windows PowerShell Web Access.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see Step 3: Configure a restrictive authorization rule and Authorization Rules and Security Features of Windows PowerShell Web Access.

trans-unit.source: To configure the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway with a genuine certificate by using Install-PswaWebApplication and IIS Manager
trans-unit.target: To configure the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway with a genuine certificate by using Install-PswaWebApplication and IIS Manager

trans-unit.source: Do one of the following to open a Windows PowerShell session.
trans-unit.target: Do one of the following to open a Windows PowerShell session.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows desktop, right-click **Windows PowerShell** on the taskbar.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows desktop, right-click **Windows PowerShell** on the taskbar.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows **Start** screen, click **Windows PowerShell**.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows **Start** screen, click **Windows PowerShell**.

trans-unit.source: Type the following, and then press **Enter**.
trans-unit.target: Type the following, and then press **Enter**.

trans-unit.source: **Install-PswaWebApplication**
trans-unit.target: **Install-PswaWebApplication**

trans-unit.source: The following gateway settings are configured by running the cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: The following gateway settings are configured by running the cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: You can change these manually in the IIS Manager console, if desired.
trans-unit.target: You can change these manually in the IIS Manager console, if desired.

trans-unit.source: You can also specify values for the WebsiteName and WebApplicationName parameters of the Install-PswaWebApplication cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can also specify values for the WebsiteName and WebApplicationName parameters of the Install-PswaWebApplication cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Path: /pswa
trans-unit.target: Path: /pswa

trans-unit.source: ApplicationPool: pswa_pool
trans-unit.target: ApplicationPool: pswa_pool

trans-unit.source: EnabledProtocols: http
trans-unit.target: EnabledProtocols: http

trans-unit.source: PhysicalPath: %*windir*%/Web/PowerShellWebAccess/wwwroot
trans-unit.target: PhysicalPath: %*windir*%/Web/PowerShellWebAccess/wwwroot

trans-unit.source: Open the IIS Manager console by doing one of the following.
trans-unit.target: Open the IIS Manager console by doing one of the following.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows desktop, start Server Manager by clicking **Server Manager** in the Windows taskbar.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows desktop, start Server Manager by clicking **Server Manager** in the Windows taskbar.

trans-unit.source: On the **Tools** menu in Server Manager, click **Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Tools** menu in Server Manager, click **Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager**.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows **Start** screen, click **Server Manager**.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows **Start** screen, click **Server Manager**.

trans-unit.source: In the IIS Manager tree pane, expand the node for the server on which Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed until the **Sites** folder is visible.
trans-unit.target: In the IIS Manager tree pane, expand the node for the server on which Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed until the **Sites** folder is visible.

trans-unit.source: Expand the **Sites** folder.
trans-unit.target: Expand the **Sites** folder.

trans-unit.source: Select the website in which you have installed the Windows PowerShell Web Access web application.
trans-unit.target: Select the website in which you have installed the Windows PowerShell Web Access web application.

trans-unit.source: In the **Actions** pane, click **Bindings**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Actions** pane, click **Bindings**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Site Binding** dialog box, click **Add**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Site Binding** dialog box, click **Add**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Add Site Binding** dialog box, in the **Type** field, select **https**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Add Site Binding** dialog box, in the **Type** field, select **https**.

trans-unit.source: In the **SSL certificate** field, select your signed certificate from the drop-down menu.
trans-unit.target: In the **SSL certificate** field, select your signed certificate from the drop-down menu.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: See [To configure an SSL certificate in IIS Manager](#BKMK_cert) in this topic for more information about how to obtain a certificate.
trans-unit.target: See [To configure an SSL certificate in IIS Manager](#BKMK_cert) in this topic for more information about how to obtain a certificate.

trans-unit.source: The Windows PowerShell Web Access web application is now configured to use your signed SSL certificate.
trans-unit.target: The Windows PowerShell Web Access web application is now configured to use your signed SSL certificate.

trans-unit.source: You can access Windows PowerShell Web Access by opening https://<server_name>/pswa in a browser window.
trans-unit.target: You can access Windows PowerShell Web Access by opening https://<server_name>/pswa in a browser window.

trans-unit.source: Note
trans-unit.target: Note

trans-unit.source: You cannot sign in until users have been granted access to the website by adding authorization rules.
trans-unit.target: You cannot sign in until users have been granted access to the website by adding authorization rules.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see Step 3: Configure a restrictive authorization rule and Authorization Rules and Security Features of Windows PowerShell Web Access.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see Step 3: Configure a restrictive authorization rule and Authorization Rules and Security Features of Windows PowerShell Web Access.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Configure a restrictive authorization rule
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Configure a restrictive authorization rule

trans-unit.source: After Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed and the gateway is configured, users can open the sign-in page in a browser, but they cannot sign in until the Windows PowerShell Web Access administrator grants users access explicitly.
trans-unit.target: After Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed and the gateway is configured, users can open the sign-in page in a browser, but they cannot sign in until the Windows PowerShell Web Access administrator grants users access explicitly.

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell Web Access access control is managed by using the set of Windows PowerShell cmdlets described in the following table.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell Web Access access control is managed by using the set of Windows PowerShell cmdlets described in the following table.

trans-unit.source: There is no comparable GUI for adding or managing authorization rules.
trans-unit.target: There is no comparable GUI for adding or managing authorization rules.

trans-unit.source: For more detailed information about Windows PowerShell Web Access cmdlets, see the cmdlet reference topics, [Windows PowerShell Web Access Cmdlets](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh918342.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more detailed information about Windows PowerShell Web Access cmdlets, see the cmdlet reference topics, [Windows PowerShell Web Access Cmdlets](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh918342.aspx).

trans-unit.source: For more detail about Windows PowerShell Web Access authorization rules and security, see [Authorization Rules and Security Features of Windows PowerShell Web Access](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn282394(v=ws.11).aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more detail about Windows PowerShell Web Access authorization rules and security, see [Authorization Rules and Security Features of Windows PowerShell Web Access](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn282394(v=ws.11).aspx).

trans-unit.source: To add a restrictive authorization rule
trans-unit.target: To add a restrictive authorization rule

trans-unit.source: Do one of the following to open a Windows PowerShell session with elevated user rights.
trans-unit.target: Do one of the following to open a Windows PowerShell session with elevated user rights.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows desktop, right-click **Windows PowerShell** on the taskbar, and then click **Run as Administrator**.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows desktop, right-click **Windows PowerShell** on the taskbar, and then click **Run as Administrator**.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows **Start** screen, right-click **Windows PowerShell**, and then click **Run as Administrator**.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows **Start** screen, right-click **Windows PowerShell**, and then click **Run as Administrator**.

trans-unit.source: Optional step for restricting user access by using session configurations: Verify that session configurations that you want to use in your rules already exist.
trans-unit.target: Optional step for restricting user access by using session configurations: Verify that session configurations that you want to use in your rules already exist.

trans-unit.source: If they have not yet been created, use instructions for creating session configurations in [about_Session_Configuration_Files](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/hh847838.aspx) on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: If they have not yet been created, use instructions for creating session configurations in [about_Session_Configuration_Files](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/hh847838.aspx) on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: Type the following, and then press **Enter**.
trans-unit.target: Type the following, and then press **Enter**.

trans-unit.source: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_f9e7959b-75d0-4d63-8f8e-02334a8dd09d'); "Copy to clipboard.")
trans-unit.target: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_f9e7959b-75d0-4d63-8f8e-02334a8dd09d'); "Copy to clipboard.")

trans-unit.source: This authorization rule allows a specific user access to one computer on the network to which they typically have access, with access to a specific session configuration that is scoped to the user’s typical scripting and cmdlet needs.
trans-unit.target: This authorization rule allows a specific user access to one computer on the network to which they typically have access, with access to a specific session configuration that is scoped to the user’s typical scripting and cmdlet needs.

trans-unit.source: In the following example, a user named JSmith in the Contoso domain is granted access to manage the computer Contoso_214, and use a session configuration named NewAdminsOnly.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, a user named JSmith in the Contoso domain is granted access to manage the computer Contoso_214, and use a session configuration named NewAdminsOnly.

trans-unit.source: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_ebd5bc5e-ec5d-4955-a86a-63843e480e37'); "Copy to clipboard.")
trans-unit.target: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_ebd5bc5e-ec5d-4955-a86a-63843e480e37'); "Copy to clipboard.")

trans-unit.source: Verify that the rule has been created by running either the **Get-PswaAuthorizationRule** cmdlet, or **Test-PswaAuthorizationRule -UserName <domain\\user | computer\\user> -ComputerName** <computer_name>.
trans-unit.target: Verify that the rule has been created by running either the **Get-PswaAuthorizationRule** cmdlet, or **Test-PswaAuthorizationRule -UserName <domain\\user | computer\\user> -ComputerName** <computer_name>.

trans-unit.source: For example, **Test-PswaAuthorizationRule –UserName Contoso\\JSmith –ComputerName Contoso_214**.
trans-unit.target: For example, **Test-PswaAuthorizationRule –UserName Contoso\\JSmith –ComputerName Contoso_214**.

trans-unit.source: After you have configured an authorization rule, you are ready for authorized users to sign in to the web-based console and begin using Windows PowerShell Web Access.
trans-unit.target: After you have configured an authorization rule, you are ready for authorized users to sign in to the web-based console and begin using Windows PowerShell Web Access.

trans-unit.source: Custom deployment
trans-unit.target: Custom deployment

trans-unit.source: You can install the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway on a server that is running Windows Server 2012 R2 or Windows Server 2012 by using the Add Roles and Features Wizard in Server Manager.
trans-unit.target: You can install the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway on a server that is running Windows Server 2012 R2 or Windows Server 2012 by using the Add Roles and Features Wizard in Server Manager.

trans-unit.source: After Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed, you can customize the configuration of the gateway in IIS Manager.
trans-unit.target: After Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed, you can customize the configuration of the gateway in IIS Manager.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Install Windows PowerShell Web Access
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Install Windows PowerShell Web Access

trans-unit.source: To install Windows PowerShell Web Access by using the Add Roles and Features Wizard
trans-unit.target: To install Windows PowerShell Web Access by using the Add Roles and Features Wizard

trans-unit.source: If Server Manager is already open, go on to the next step.
trans-unit.target: If Server Manager is already open, go on to the next step.

trans-unit.source: If Server Manager is not already open, open it by doing one of the following.
trans-unit.target: If Server Manager is not already open, open it by doing one of the following.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows desktop, start Server Manager by clicking **Server Manager** in the Windows taskbar.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows desktop, start Server Manager by clicking **Server Manager** in the Windows taskbar.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows **Start** screen, click **Server Manager**.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows **Start** screen, click **Server Manager**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Manage** menu, click **Add Roles and Features**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Manage** menu, click **Add Roles and Features**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Select installation type** page, select **Role-based or feature-based installation**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Select installation type** page, select **Role-based or feature-based installation**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Select destination server** page, select a server from the server pool, or select an offline VHD.
trans-unit.target: On the **Select destination server** page, select a server from the server pool, or select an offline VHD.

trans-unit.source: To select an offline VHD as your destination server, first select the server on which to mount the VHD, and then select the VHD file.
trans-unit.target: To select an offline VHD as your destination server, first select the server on which to mount the VHD, and then select the VHD file.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to add servers to your server pool, see the Server Manager Help.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to add servers to your server pool, see the Server Manager Help.

trans-unit.source: After you have selected the destination server, click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: After you have selected the destination server, click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Select features** page of the wizard, expand **Windows PowerShell**, and then select **Windows PowerShell Web Access**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Select features** page of the wizard, expand **Windows PowerShell**, and then select **Windows PowerShell Web Access**.

trans-unit.source: Note that you are prompted to add required features, such as .NET Framework 4.5, and role services of Web Server (IIS).
trans-unit.target: Note that you are prompted to add required features, such as .NET Framework 4.5, and role services of Web Server (IIS).

trans-unit.source: Add required features and continue.
trans-unit.target: Add required features and continue.

trans-unit.source: Note
trans-unit.target: Note

trans-unit.source: Installing Windows PowerShell Web Access by using the Add Roles and Features Wizard also installs Web Server (IIS), including the IIS Manager snap-in.
trans-unit.target: Installing Windows PowerShell Web Access by using the Add Roles and Features Wizard also installs Web Server (IIS), including the IIS Manager snap-in.

trans-unit.source: The snap-in and other IIS management tools are installed by default if you use Add Roles and Features Wizard.
trans-unit.target: The snap-in and other IIS management tools are installed by default if you use Add Roles and Features Wizard.

trans-unit.source: If you install Windows PowerShell Web Access by using Windows PowerShell cmdlets as described in the following procedure, management tools are not added by default.
trans-unit.target: If you install Windows PowerShell Web Access by using Windows PowerShell cmdlets as described in the following procedure, management tools are not added by default.

trans-unit.source: On the **Confirm installation selections** page, if the feature files for Windows PowerShell Web Access are not stored on the destination server that you selected in step 4, click **Specify an alternate source path**, and provide the path to the feature files.
trans-unit.target: On the **Confirm installation selections** page, if the feature files for Windows PowerShell Web Access are not stored on the destination server that you selected in step 4, click **Specify an alternate source path**, and provide the path to the feature files.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, click **Install**.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, click **Install**.

trans-unit.source: After you click **Install**, the **Installation progress** page displays installation progress, results, and messages such as warnings, failures, or post-installation configuration steps that are required for Windows PowerShell Web Access.
trans-unit.target: After you click **Install**, the **Installation progress** page displays installation progress, results, and messages such as warnings, failures, or post-installation configuration steps that are required for Windows PowerShell Web Access.

trans-unit.source: After Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed, you are prompted to review the readme file, which contains basic, required setup instructions for the gateway.
trans-unit.target: After Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed, you are prompted to review the readme file, which contains basic, required setup instructions for the gateway.

trans-unit.source: These instructions are also included in this topic.
trans-unit.target: These instructions are also included in this topic.

trans-unit.source: The path to the readme file is C:\\Windows\\Web\\PowerShellWebAccess\\wwwroot\\README.txt.
trans-unit.target: The path to the readme file is C:\\Windows\\Web\\PowerShellWebAccess\\wwwroot\\README.txt.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Configure the gateway
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Configure the gateway

trans-unit.source: Instructions in this section are for installing the Windows PowerShell Web Access web application in a subdirectory—and not in the root directory—of your website.
trans-unit.target: Instructions in this section are for installing the Windows PowerShell Web Access web application in a subdirectory—and not in the root directory—of your website.

trans-unit.source: This procedure is the GUI-based equivalent of the actions performed by the Install-PswaWebApplication cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: This procedure is the GUI-based equivalent of the actions performed by the Install-PswaWebApplication cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This section also includes instructions for how to use IIS Manager to configure the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway as a root website.
trans-unit.target: This section also includes instructions for how to use IIS Manager to configure the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway as a root website.

trans-unit.source: [To use IIS Manager to configure the gateway in an existing website](#BKMK_configman)
trans-unit.target: [To use IIS Manager to configure the gateway in an existing website](#BKMK_configman)

trans-unit.source: [To use IIS Manager to configure the gateway as a root website with a test certificate](#BKMK_configroot)
trans-unit.target: [To use IIS Manager to configure the gateway as a root website with a test certificate](#BKMK_configroot)

trans-unit.source: To use IIS Manager to configure the gateway in an existing website
trans-unit.target: To use IIS Manager to configure the gateway in an existing website

trans-unit.source: Open the IIS Manager console by doing one of the following.
trans-unit.target: Open the IIS Manager console by doing one of the following.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows desktop, start Server Manager by clicking **Server Manager** in the Windows taskbar.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows desktop, start Server Manager by clicking **Server Manager** in the Windows taskbar.

trans-unit.source: On the **Tools** menu in Server Manager, click **Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Tools** menu in Server Manager, click **Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager**.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows **Start** screen, type any part of the name **Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager**.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows **Start** screen, type any part of the name **Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager**.

trans-unit.source: Click the shortcut when it is displayed in the **Apps** results.
trans-unit.target: Click the shortcut when it is displayed in the **Apps** results.

trans-unit.source: Create a new application pool for Windows PowerShell Web Access.
trans-unit.target: Create a new application pool for Windows PowerShell Web Access.

trans-unit.source: Expand the node of the gateway server in the IIS Manager tree pane, select **Application Pools**, and click **Add Application Pool** in the **Actions** pane.
trans-unit.target: Expand the node of the gateway server in the IIS Manager tree pane, select **Application Pools**, and click **Add Application Pool** in the **Actions** pane.

trans-unit.source: Add a new application pool with the name **pswa_pool**, or provide another name.
trans-unit.target: Add a new application pool with the name **pswa_pool**, or provide another name.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: In the IIS Manager tree pane, expand the node for the server on which Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed until the **Sites** folder is visible.
trans-unit.target: In the IIS Manager tree pane, expand the node for the server on which Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed until the **Sites** folder is visible.

trans-unit.source: Select the **Sites** folder.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Sites** folder.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the website (for example, **Default Web Site**) to which you would like to add the Windows PowerShell Web Access website, and then click **Add Application**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the website (for example, **Default Web Site**) to which you would like to add the Windows PowerShell Web Access website, and then click **Add Application**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Alias** field, type pswa, or provide another alias.
trans-unit.target: In the **Alias** field, type pswa, or provide another alias.

trans-unit.source: The alias becomes the virtual directory name.
trans-unit.target: The alias becomes the virtual directory name.

trans-unit.source: For example, **pswa** in the following URL represents the alias specified in this step: https://<server_name>/pswa.
trans-unit.target: For example, **pswa** in the following URL represents the alias specified in this step: https://<server_name>/pswa.

trans-unit.source: In the **Application pool** field, select the application pool that you created in step 3.
trans-unit.target: In the **Application pool** field, select the application pool that you created in step 3.

trans-unit.source: In the **Physical path** field, browse for the location of the application.
trans-unit.target: In the **Physical path** field, browse for the location of the application.

trans-unit.source: You can use the default location, %windir%/Web/PowerShellWebAccess/wwwroot.
trans-unit.target: You can use the default location, %windir%/Web/PowerShellWebAccess/wwwroot.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps in the procedure [To configure an SSL certificate in IIS Manager](#BKMK_cert) in this topic.
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps in the procedure [To configure an SSL certificate in IIS Manager](#BKMK_cert) in this topic.

trans-unit.source: Optional security step: With the website selected in the tree pane, double-click **SSL Settings** in the content pane.
trans-unit.target: Optional security step: With the website selected in the tree pane, double-click **SSL Settings** in the content pane.

trans-unit.source: Select **Require SSL**, and then in the **Actions** pane, click **Apply**.
trans-unit.target: Select **Require SSL**, and then in the **Actions** pane, click **Apply**.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, in the **SSL Settings** pane, you can require that users connecting to the Windows PowerShell Web Access website have client certificates.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, in the **SSL Settings** pane, you can require that users connecting to the Windows PowerShell Web Access website have client certificates.

trans-unit.source: Client certificates help to verify the identity of a client device user.
trans-unit.target: Client certificates help to verify the identity of a client device user.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how requiring client certificates can increase the security of Windows PowerShell Web Access, see [Authorization Rules and Security Features of Windows PowerShell Web Access](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn282394(v=ws.11).aspx) in this guide.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how requiring client certificates can increase the security of Windows PowerShell Web Access, see [Authorization Rules and Security Features of Windows PowerShell Web Access](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn282394(v=ws.11).aspx) in this guide.

trans-unit.source: Open a browser session on a client device.
trans-unit.target: Open a browser session on a client device.

trans-unit.source: For more information about supported browsers and devices, see [Browser and client device support](#BKMK_browser) in this topic.
trans-unit.target: For more information about supported browsers and devices, see [Browser and client device support](#BKMK_browser) in this topic.

trans-unit.source: Open the new Windows PowerShell Web Access website, https://< *gateway_server_name*>/pswa.
trans-unit.target: Open the new Windows PowerShell Web Access website, https://< *gateway_server_name*>/pswa.

trans-unit.source: The browser should display the Windows PowerShell Web Access console sign-in page.
trans-unit.target: The browser should display the Windows PowerShell Web Access console sign-in page.

trans-unit.source: Note
trans-unit.target: Note

trans-unit.source: You cannot sign in until users have been granted access to the website by adding authorization rules.
trans-unit.target: You cannot sign in until users have been granted access to the website by adding authorization rules.

trans-unit.source: In a Windows PowerShell session that has been opened with elevated user rights (Run as Administrator), run the following script, in which *application_pool_name* represents the name of the application pool that you created in step 3, to give the application pool access rights to the authorization file.
trans-unit.target: In a Windows PowerShell session that has been opened with elevated user rights (Run as Administrator), run the following script, in which *application_pool_name* represents the name of the application pool that you created in step 3, to give the application pool access rights to the authorization file.

trans-unit.source: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_c1a80a93-8fcf-4beb-a025-5f81bfb8bdae'); "Copy to clipboard.")
trans-unit.target: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_c1a80a93-8fcf-4beb-a025-5f81bfb8bdae'); "Copy to clipboard.")

trans-unit.source: To view existing access rights on the authorization file, run the following command:
trans-unit.target: To view existing access rights on the authorization file, run the following command:

trans-unit.source: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_ac2179c2-9548-4a17-8663-267fdd105380'); "Copy to clipboard.")
trans-unit.target: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_ac2179c2-9548-4a17-8663-267fdd105380'); "Copy to clipboard.")

trans-unit.source: To use IIS Manager to configure the gateway as a root website with a test certificate
trans-unit.target: To use IIS Manager to configure the gateway as a root website with a test certificate

trans-unit.source: Open the IIS Manager console by doing one of the following.
trans-unit.target: Open the IIS Manager console by doing one of the following.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows desktop, start Server Manager by clicking **Server Manager** in the Windows taskbar.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows desktop, start Server Manager by clicking **Server Manager** in the Windows taskbar.

trans-unit.source: On the **Tools** menu in Server Manager, click **Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Tools** menu in Server Manager, click **Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager**.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows **Start** screen, type any part of the name **Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager**.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows **Start** screen, type any part of the name **Internet Information Services (IIS) Manager**.

trans-unit.source: Click the shortcut when it is displayed in the **Apps** results.
trans-unit.target: Click the shortcut when it is displayed in the **Apps** results.

trans-unit.source: In the IIS Manager tree pane, expand the node for the server on which Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed until the **Sites** folder is visible.
trans-unit.target: In the IIS Manager tree pane, expand the node for the server on which Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed until the **Sites** folder is visible.

trans-unit.source: Select the **Sites** folder.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Sites** folder.

trans-unit.source: In the **Actions** pane, click **Add Website**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Actions** pane, click **Add Website**.

trans-unit.source: Type a name for the website, such as **Windows PowerShell Web Access**.
trans-unit.target: Type a name for the website, such as **Windows PowerShell Web Access**.

trans-unit.source: An application pool is automatically created for the new website.
trans-unit.target: An application pool is automatically created for the new website.

trans-unit.source: To use a different application pool, click **Select** to select an application pool to associate with the new website.
trans-unit.target: To use a different application pool, click **Select** to select an application pool to associate with the new website.

trans-unit.source: Select the alternate application pool in the **Select Application Pool** dialog box, and then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Select the alternate application pool in the **Select Application Pool** dialog box, and then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Physical path** text box, navigate to %*windir*%/Web/PowerShellWebAccess/wwwroot.
trans-unit.target: In the **Physical path** text box, navigate to %*windir*%/Web/PowerShellWebAccess/wwwroot.

trans-unit.source: In the **Type** field of the **Binding** area, select **https**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Type** field of the **Binding** area, select **https**.

trans-unit.source: Assign a port number to the website that is not already in use by another site or application.
trans-unit.target: Assign a port number to the website that is not already in use by another site or application.

trans-unit.source: To locate open ports, you can run the **netstat** command in a Command Prompt window.
trans-unit.target: To locate open ports, you can run the **netstat** command in a Command Prompt window.

trans-unit.source: The default port number is 443.
trans-unit.target: The default port number is 443.

trans-unit.source: Change the default port if another website is already using 443, or if you have other security reasons for changing the port number.
trans-unit.target: Change the default port if another website is already using 443, or if you have other security reasons for changing the port number.

trans-unit.source: If another website that is running on your gateway server is using your selected port, a warning is displayed when you click **OK** in the **Add Website** dialog box.
trans-unit.target: If another website that is running on your gateway server is using your selected port, a warning is displayed when you click **OK** in the **Add Website** dialog box.

trans-unit.source: You must use an unused port to run Windows PowerShell Web Access.
trans-unit.target: You must use an unused port to run Windows PowerShell Web Access.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, if needed for your organization, specify a host name that makes sense to your organization and users, such as **www.contoso.com**.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, if needed for your organization, specify a host name that makes sense to your organization and users, such as **www.contoso.com**.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: For a more secure production environment, we strongly recommend providing a valid certificate that has been signed by a CA.
trans-unit.target: For a more secure production environment, we strongly recommend providing a valid certificate that has been signed by a CA.

trans-unit.source: You must provide an SSL certificate, because users can only connect to Windows PowerShell Web Access through an HTTPS website.
trans-unit.target: You must provide an SSL certificate, because users can only connect to Windows PowerShell Web Access through an HTTPS website.

trans-unit.source: See [To configure an SSL certificate in IIS Manager](#BKMK_cert) in this topic for more information about how to obtain a certificate.
trans-unit.target: See [To configure an SSL certificate in IIS Manager](#BKMK_cert) in this topic for more information about how to obtain a certificate.

trans-unit.source: Click **OK** to close the **Add Website** dialog box.
trans-unit.target: Click **OK** to close the **Add Website** dialog box.

trans-unit.source: In a Windows PowerShell session that has been opened with elevated user rights (Run as Administrator), run the following script, in which *application_pool_name* represents the name of the application pool that you created in step 4, to give the application pool access rights to the authorization file.
trans-unit.target: In a Windows PowerShell session that has been opened with elevated user rights (Run as Administrator), run the following script, in which *application_pool_name* represents the name of the application pool that you created in step 4, to give the application pool access rights to the authorization file.

trans-unit.source: To view existing access rights on the authorization file, run the following command:
trans-unit.target: To view existing access rights on the authorization file, run the following command:

trans-unit.source: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_0eb6d70a-2807-498b-b088-fa5233ed68d5'); "Copy to clipboard.")
trans-unit.target: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_0eb6d70a-2807-498b-b088-fa5233ed68d5'); "Copy to clipboard.")

trans-unit.source: With the new website selected in the IIS Manager tree pane, click **Start** in the **Actions** pane to start the website.
trans-unit.target: With the new website selected in the IIS Manager tree pane, click **Start** in the **Actions** pane to start the website.

trans-unit.source: Open a browser session on a client device.
trans-unit.target: Open a browser session on a client device.

trans-unit.source: For more information about supported browsers and devices, see [Browser and client device support](#BKMK_browser) in this document.
trans-unit.target: For more information about supported browsers and devices, see [Browser and client device support](#BKMK_browser) in this document.

trans-unit.source: Open the new Windows PowerShell Web Access website.
trans-unit.target: Open the new Windows PowerShell Web Access website.

trans-unit.source: Because the root website points to the Windows PowerShell Web Access folder, the browser should display the Windows PowerShell Web Access sign-in page when you open https://< *gateway_server_name*>.
trans-unit.target: Because the root website points to the Windows PowerShell Web Access folder, the browser should display the Windows PowerShell Web Access sign-in page when you open https://< *gateway_server_name*>.

trans-unit.source: You should not need to add **/pswa** to the URL.
trans-unit.target: You should not need to add **/pswa** to the URL.

trans-unit.source: Note
trans-unit.target: Note

trans-unit.source: You cannot sign in until users have been granted access to the website by adding authorization rules.
trans-unit.target: You cannot sign in until users have been granted access to the website by adding authorization rules.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Configure a restrictive authorization rule
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Configure a restrictive authorization rule

trans-unit.source: After Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed and the gateway is configured, users can open the sign-in page in a browser, but they cannot sign in until the Windows PowerShell Web Access administrator grants users access explicitly.
trans-unit.target: After Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed and the gateway is configured, users can open the sign-in page in a browser, but they cannot sign in until the Windows PowerShell Web Access administrator grants users access explicitly.

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell Web Access access control is managed by using the set of Windows PowerShell cmdlets described in the following table.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell Web Access access control is managed by using the set of Windows PowerShell cmdlets described in the following table.

trans-unit.source: There is no comparable GUI for adding or managing authorization rules.
trans-unit.target: There is no comparable GUI for adding or managing authorization rules.

trans-unit.source: For more detailed information about Windows PowerShell Web Access cmdlets, see the cmdlet reference topics, [Windows PowerShell Web Access Cmdlets](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh918342.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more detailed information about Windows PowerShell Web Access cmdlets, see the cmdlet reference topics, [Windows PowerShell Web Access Cmdlets](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/hh918342.aspx).

trans-unit.source: For more detail about Windows PowerShell Web Access authorization rules and security, see [Authorization Rules and Security Features of Windows PowerShell Web Access](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn282394(v=ws.11).aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more detail about Windows PowerShell Web Access authorization rules and security, see [Authorization Rules and Security Features of Windows PowerShell Web Access](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn282394(v=ws.11).aspx).

trans-unit.source: To add a restrictive authorization rule
trans-unit.target: To add a restrictive authorization rule

trans-unit.source: Do one of the following to open a Windows PowerShell session with elevated user rights.
trans-unit.target: Do one of the following to open a Windows PowerShell session with elevated user rights.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows desktop, right-click **Windows PowerShell** on the taskbar, and then click **Run as Administrator**.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows desktop, right-click **Windows PowerShell** on the taskbar, and then click **Run as Administrator**.

trans-unit.source: On the Windows **Start** screen, right-click **Windows PowerShell**, and then click **Run as Administrator**.
trans-unit.target: On the Windows **Start** screen, right-click **Windows PowerShell**, and then click **Run as Administrator**.

trans-unit.source: Optional step for restricting user access by using session configurations: Verify that session configurations that you want to use in your rules already exist.
trans-unit.target: Optional step for restricting user access by using session configurations: Verify that session configurations that you want to use in your rules already exist.

trans-unit.source: If they have not yet been created, use instructions for creating session configurations in [about_Session_Configuration_Files](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/hh847838.aspx) on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: If they have not yet been created, use instructions for creating session configurations in [about_Session_Configuration_Files](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/hh847838.aspx) on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: Type the following, and then press **Enter**.
trans-unit.target: Type the following, and then press **Enter**.

trans-unit.source: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_4df22c91-f56f-4bb5-91e7-99f9b365ed5d'); "Copy to clipboard.")
trans-unit.target: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_4df22c91-f56f-4bb5-91e7-99f9b365ed5d'); "Copy to clipboard.")

trans-unit.source: This authorization rule allows a specific user access to one computer on the network to which they typically have access, with access to a specific session configuration that is scoped to the user’s typical scripting and cmdlet needs.
trans-unit.target: This authorization rule allows a specific user access to one computer on the network to which they typically have access, with access to a specific session configuration that is scoped to the user’s typical scripting and cmdlet needs.

trans-unit.source: In the following example, a user named JSmith in the Contoso domain is granted access to manage the computer Contoso_214, and use a session configuration named NewAdminsOnly.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, a user named JSmith in the Contoso domain is granted access to manage the computer Contoso_214, and use a session configuration named NewAdminsOnly.

trans-unit.source: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_efc3999a-2905-453f-86cd-014b41658ffc'); "Copy to clipboard.")
trans-unit.target: [Copy](javascript:if%20(window.epx.codeSnippet)window.epx.codeSnippet.copyCode('CodeSnippetContainerCode_efc3999a-2905-453f-86cd-014b41658ffc'); "Copy to clipboard.")

trans-unit.source: Verify that the rule has been created by running either the **Get-PswaAuthorizationRule** cmdlet, or **Test-PswaAuthorizationRule -UserName <domain\\user | computer\\user> -ComputerName** <computer_name>.
trans-unit.target: Verify that the rule has been created by running either the **Get-PswaAuthorizationRule** cmdlet, or **Test-PswaAuthorizationRule -UserName <domain\\user | computer\\user> -ComputerName** <computer_name>.

trans-unit.source: For example, **Test-PswaAuthorizationRule –UserName Contoso\\JSmith –ComputerName Contoso_214**.
trans-unit.target: For example, **Test-PswaAuthorizationRule –UserName Contoso\\JSmith –ComputerName Contoso_214**.

trans-unit.source: After you have configured an authorization rule, you are ready for authorized users to sign in to the web-based console and begin using Windows PowerShell Web Access.
trans-unit.target: After you have configured an authorization rule, you are ready for authorized users to sign in to the web-based console and begin using Windows PowerShell Web Access.

trans-unit.source: Configure a genuine certificate
trans-unit.target: Configure a genuine certificate

trans-unit.source: For a secure production environment, always use a valid SSL certificate that has been signed by a certification authority (CA).
trans-unit.target: For a secure production environment, always use a valid SSL certificate that has been signed by a certification authority (CA).

trans-unit.source: The procedure in this section describes how to obtain and apply a valid SSL certificate from a CA.
trans-unit.target: The procedure in this section describes how to obtain and apply a valid SSL certificate from a CA.

trans-unit.source: To configure an SSL certificate in IIS Manager
trans-unit.target: To configure an SSL certificate in IIS Manager

trans-unit.source: In the IIS Manager tree pane, select the server on which Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed.
trans-unit.target: In the IIS Manager tree pane, select the server on which Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed.

trans-unit.source: In the content pane, double click **Server Certificates**.
trans-unit.target: In the content pane, double click **Server Certificates**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Actions** pane, do one of the following.
trans-unit.target: In the **Actions** pane, do one of the following.

trans-unit.source: For more information about configuring server certificates in IIS, see [Configuring Server Certificates in IIS 7](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc732230.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about configuring server certificates in IIS, see [Configuring Server Certificates in IIS 7](https://technet.microsoft.com/library/cc732230.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Click **Import** to import an existing, valid certificate from a location on your network.
trans-unit.target: Click **Import** to import an existing, valid certificate from a location on your network.

trans-unit.source: Click **Create Certificate Request** to request a certificate from a CA such as VeriSign™, Thawte, or GeoTrust®.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create Certificate Request** to request a certificate from a CA such as VeriSign™, Thawte, or GeoTrust®.

trans-unit.source: The certificate's common name must match the host header in the request.
trans-unit.target: The certificate's common name must match the host header in the request.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the client browser requests http://www.contoso.com/, then the common name must also be http://www.contoso.com/.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the client browser requests http://www.contoso.com/, then the common name must also be http://www.contoso.com/.

trans-unit.source: This is the most secure and recommended option for providing the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway with a certificate.
trans-unit.target: This is the most secure and recommended option for providing the Windows PowerShell Web Access gateway with a certificate.

trans-unit.source: Click **Create a Self-Signed Certificate** to create a certificate that you can use immediately, and have signed later by a CA if desired.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create a Self-Signed Certificate** to create a certificate that you can use immediately, and have signed later by a CA if desired.

trans-unit.source: Specify a friendly name for the self-signed certificate, such as **Windows PowerShell Web Access**.
trans-unit.target: Specify a friendly name for the self-signed certificate, such as **Windows PowerShell Web Access**.

trans-unit.source: This option is not considered secure, and is recommended only for a private test environment.
trans-unit.target: This option is not considered secure, and is recommended only for a private test environment.

trans-unit.source: After creating or obtaining a certificate, select the website to which the certificate is applied (for example, **Default Web Site**) in the IIS Manager tree pane, and then click **Bindings** in the **Actions** pane.
trans-unit.target: After creating or obtaining a certificate, select the website to which the certificate is applied (for example, **Default Web Site**) in the IIS Manager tree pane, and then click **Bindings** in the **Actions** pane.

trans-unit.source: In the **Add Site Binding** dialog box, add an **https** binding for the site, if one is not already displayed.
trans-unit.target: In the **Add Site Binding** dialog box, add an **https** binding for the site, if one is not already displayed.

trans-unit.source: If you are not using a self-signed certificate, specify the host name from step 3 of this procedure.
trans-unit.target: If you are not using a self-signed certificate, specify the host name from step 3 of this procedure.

trans-unit.source: If you are using a self-signed certificate, this step is not required.
trans-unit.target: If you are using a self-signed certificate, this step is not required.

trans-unit.source: Select the certificate that you obtained or created in step 3 of this procedure, and then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Select the certificate that you obtained or created in step 3 of this procedure, and then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Using the web-based Windows PowerShell console
trans-unit.target: Using the web-based Windows PowerShell console

trans-unit.source: After Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed and the gateway configuration is finished as described in this topic, the Windows PowerShell web-based console is ready to use.
trans-unit.target: After Windows PowerShell Web Access is installed and the gateway configuration is finished as described in this topic, the Windows PowerShell web-based console is ready to use.

trans-unit.source: For more information about getting started in the web-based console, see [Use the Web-based Windows PowerShell Console](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh831417(v=ws.11).aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about getting started in the web-based console, see [Use the Web-based Windows PowerShell Console](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh831417(v=ws.11).aspx).
